intro: Orthocarpus laciniatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved orthocarpus, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky soils. Its leaves are finely divided, giving it a feathery appearance, and it produces small, white to greenish flowers that bloom in early spring. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
